item.itunes:summary: It seems as if we Unitarians are quick to tell others what we don'tbelieve. What can we tell our children about what we dobelieve? A discussion of the Seven Principles of our Unitarian Universalist Faith.

item.title: Approaching Tao
item.itunes:author: Kevin Ballard
item.itunes:subtitle: Sunday, January 7, 2001
item.itunes:summary: A broad survey of Taoism, its practice and its philosophy. And an appreciation of some similarities between Taoism and the philosophy of Unitarian Universalists.

item.title: Will You Please Be Quiet, Please? And other Christmas Thoughts
item.itunes:author: Steve Wiegenstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Sunday, December 10, 2000
item.itunes:summary: The Christmas story tells us that holiness sometimes breaks into our lives unexpectedly, unasked-for; and that if we can be open to these moments our world can suddenly blossom and be transformed.

item.title: What Mean These Stones?
item.itunes:author: Rev. Dr. Rob Manning
item.itunes:subtitle: Veteran's Day, November 11, 2000
item.itunes:summary: Cultural Memory and the meaning of the past. Reflections upon our rememberance during a day set aside for remembering.

item.title: Playing the Church Game
item.itunes:author: Ellen Taylor
item.itunes:subtitle: Sunday, September 17, 2000
item.itunes:summary: A powerfully perceptive response to Ellen's personal questioning. Why do we bother with coming to church? What is it that Unitarians find so compelling about coming to this place and being with these people?

item.title: Growing up as a UU
item.itunes:author: Kristina Mathieson
item.itunes:subtitle: Sunday, May 7, 2000
item.itunes:summary: In honor of our graduating High School Seniors, we annually designate one Sunday as "Youth Sunday." We are extremely proud of our graduates, and we are happy to share the address that Kristina presented on "Youth Sunday, 2000."

item.title: Surfing Toward Bethlehem
item.itunes:author: Steve Wiegenstein
item.itunes:subtitle: Sunday, March 26, 2000
item.itunes:summary: Can a person be an inhabitant of this media-saturated era without falling prey to its twin influences of superficiality and self-absorption? The key is to make sure that you are using the technology, and not the other way around.

item.title: Christians and Pagans and Satan, Oh My!
item.itunes:author: Paul Miller
item.itunes:subtitle: Sunday, February 20, 2000
item.itunes:summary: Let us draw a distinction between those who call themselves "Pagans" and those who call themselves "Satanists." While we're at it, let us illuminate a few of the sins of the Christians, too. A discussion of the "Nine Satanic Statements."

item.title: The Four Faces of Jesus
item.itunes:author: Dr. Davidson Loehr
item.itunes:subtitle: Sunday, January 30, 2000
item.itunes:summary: We invited Dr. Loehr to Quincy to present a weekend workshop on the Jesus Seminar. His Sunday Address presented an historical view of the person named "Jesus."

item.title: Overcoming Christianity
item.itunes:author: Rev. Dr. Rob Manning
item.itunes:subtitle: Easter Sunday, April 4, 1999
item.itunes:summary: Martin Luther King would tell us that all who work for justice have cosmic companionship. God, as a spirit who helps us to overcome, is the meaning of Christ's resurrection.

item.title: The Morality of a Broad & Comprehensive Education
item.itunes:author: Ellen Taylor
item.itunes:subtitle: Sunday, March 21, 1999
item.itunes:summary: Ellen's vision of Morality and Education was presented to us before Quincy's Public School Administration was re-invented during the Spring of 1999.

item.title: What is Prayer & Do Unitarians Pray?
item.itunes:author: Carol Nichols
item.itunes:subtitle: Sunday, February 28, 1999
item.itunes:summary: A broad survey of the meaning of the word, "Prayer," and of the meaning that prayer can add to Unitarian Lives. Think of prayer as ". . . that which will center you and help you live your brief life with a spark of the Divine."

item.title: A Lonely Minority
item.itunes:author: Dr. John Sperry
item.itunes:subtitle: Sunday, December 27, 1998
item.itunes:summary: Reflections upon the relationship between Unitarian Universalist Congregations and those members who characterize themselves as "Christians."

item.title: Why do we Need Funerals?
item.itunes:author: Rev. Allen Peyton
item.itunes:subtitle: Sunday, October 11, 1998
item.itunes:summary: An anthropological search for the biological and psychological underpinnings of our need for the rituals which solemnize the deaths of our loved ones.

item.title: Christianity and the Care of the Self
item.itunes:author: Rev. Dr. Rob Manning
item.itunes:subtitle: Sunday, November 9, 1997
item.itunes:summary: Does Christianity have as one of its central concerns, and does it treasure and promote what Michel Foucault presented to us as the central concern of both Greek and Roman cultures; "the care of the self"?

item.title: The Specter of Marx: Labor, Alienation, the Caterpillar and the Silkworm
item.itunes:author: Rev. Dr. Rob Manning
item.itunes:subtitle: Sunday, October 19, 1997
item.itunes:summary: Since we give so much of our lives to our work; our best sort of work should be the kind which enables us to become who we really want to be.

item.title: On World Religion
item.itunes:author: Michael Flanagan
item.itunes:subtitle: Sunday, September 21, 1997
item.itunes:summary: An attempt to unify the religions of the world. What might ALL of the world's religions have in common?

item.title: Love as Strong as Death
item.itunes:author: Rev. Dr. Rob Manning
item.itunes:subtitle: Sunday, February 23, 1997
item.itunes:summary: Life's toughest battles are fought inside people's hearts as they struggle with the despair, pain and hopelessness brought to them, without their choice, by death's power to take away.

item.title: Uprooted and/or Transplanted
item.itunes:author: Rev. Dr. Rob Manning
item.itunes:subtitle: Sunday, November 17, 1996
item.itunes:summary: In an afternoon ceremony on the same day, Dr. Robert J. S. Manning was formally ordained and installed as the minister of the Quincy Unitarian Church. In his morning talk, Rob pledged to resist becoming "settled."

item.title: I am Haunted by Waters
item.itunes:author: Captain Michael Flanagan
item.itunes:subtitle: Sunday, October 13, 1996
item.itunes:summary: The value of a life lived on the Mississippi River during the latter half of the Twentieth Century.

item.title: Jesus, God, Etc.
item.itunes:author: Rev. Lynn S. Smith-Roberts
item.itunes:subtitle: Sunday, May 5, 1991
item.itunes:summary: In this, the second of a two part series titled "What Unitarian Universalists Believe," our minister describes aspects of the many relationships among God-talk, Christianity and Unitarian Universalism.

item.title: Religion? Without God?
item.itunes:author: Rev. Lynn S. Smith-Roberts
item.itunes:subtitle: Sunday, April 7, 1991
item.itunes:summary: Our minister presented a two part series that she titled "What Unitarian Universalists Believe." Her defense of Humanism came first.

item.title: The Edge of the Sea
item.itunes:author: Nike Mendenhall
item.itunes:subtitle: Sunday, November 11, 1990
item.itunes:summary: A discussion of the importance of the oceans to those of us who live in the centers of continents.

item.title: Our Four Churches, Their Celebrations and People
item.itunes:author: Dienna Drew
item.itunes:subtitle: Sunday, December 17, 1989
item.itunes:summary: A short history of the church buildings that we have occupied since our organization in 1839.

item.title: The Oracles of Concord: Emerson, Thoreau, Alcott, and George Melvin
item.itunes:author: Rev. John W. Brigham, D.D.
item.itunes:subtitle: Sunday, June 3, 1983
item.itunes:summary: Dr. Brigham recalls the portion of Unitarian history that grew from Concord, Massachusetts, his home town.

item.title: The Moral Confusion of Religious Zealots
item.itunes:author: Rev. John W. Brigham, D.D.
item.itunes:subtitle: Sunday, March 15, 1981
item.itunes:summary: When personal judgement is surrendered to a movement, the individual's moral sense becomes vulnerable to the judgement of the collective.

item.title: . . . all we value here
item.itunes:author: Rev. John W. Brigham, D.D.
item.itunes:subtitle: Sunday, March 10, 1985 - to the First Unitarian Church of Sioux City, Iowa
item.itunes:summary: In 1985 Dr.Brigham was asked to join in the Centennial celebration of the Unitarian Congregation in Sioux City, Iowa, where he had been minister many years before.

item.title: This Mad World on its Way to Nowhere
item.itunes:author: Rev. John W. Brigham, D.D.
item.itunes:subtitle: Sunday, March 4, 1979 - to the Burlington, Iowa Unitarian Universalist Fellowship
item.itunes:summary: The human unreasonableness of many "perfectly reasonable" public policy positions.

item.title: A Walk in the City
item.itunes:author: Rev. John W. Brigham, D.D.
item.itunes:subtitle: Sunday, April 7, 1968 - to the First Universalist Church of Rochester, NY
item.itunes:summary: A Palm Sunday sermon, given on the Sunday following the assassination of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. What would be a fitting and proper sort of memorial to the life of this remarkable man?
